title: How is the Fair Debts Collection Practices Act a defense to an unlawful detainer case?
question: My sister-in-law owns property and is in the process of evicting her tenants. One of the defenses in the paperwork they gave her is her evicting them violates the FDCPA, how does this apply?
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Real estate and bankruptcy,Landlord or tenant,Tenant rights,Eviction from rental property,Real estate
answers: It generally should not apply, but you should have an attorney review your sister-in-law's case and to represent her at the trial, if there is one. Without seeing the actual answer and knowing additional facts, it is difficult to say whether or not it applies.

I am sorry your sister is going through this. Fair Debt Collection Practices Act is a statute that protects consumers from third party collectors wrongdoings. I have a legal guide on my page that can get your more information on the CFPB and the FDCPA. Here, your sister is the owner of the property. She should not be bound by the FDCPA, even with collecting the rent. Are you sure that this is the law the tenant is quoting?
have her attorney review the tenant answer. Generally they throw in a bunch of unnecessary and irrelevant defenses especially if representing themselves.
